question_text: Based on the provided paper content, explain how the charge density of metal cations affects the thermal stability of nitrate salt mixtures used in concentrating solar power applications. Compare the effects of alkali cations (Na+, K+, Li+) versus calcium cations (Ca2+) and describe the underlying molecular mechanism that leads to reduced thermal stability with higher charge density cations.
standard_answer: The thermal stability of nitrate salt mixtures is fundamentally governed by the charge density of the metal cations present in the system. According to the paper, 'Yuvaraj et al. [71] determined the thermal stability of different single nitrate salts in air and hydrogen concluding, that the thermal stability is inversely correlated with the charge density [...] of the metal cation.' This inverse relationship means that cations with higher charge density lead to lower thermal stability. Alkali cations like Na+, K+, and Li+ have relatively low charge densities due to their +1 charge and larger ionic radii, resulting in better thermal stability. In contrast, calcium cations (Ca2+) possess a higher charge density due to their +2 charge, despite having a similar ionic radius to sodium (Ca2+ ≈ 100 pm, Na+ ≈ 102 pm). The mechanism involves electrostatic interactions where 'cations with a high charge density (ratio of charge to volume) polarize the electronic cloud of the nitrate ion [...] Both effects lead to a formal reduction of the bond order and thus a weakening of the N–O bond.' This bond weakening lowers the activation energy for decomposition pathways, making calcium-containing nitrate mixtures less thermally stable than alkali-only systems like Solar Salt. Consequently, calcium-containing salts exhibit earlier onset of decomposition and reduced maximum operating temperatures in CSP applications.

The molecular mechanism is correctly described: high charge density cations polarize the nitrate ion's electronic cloud, weakening N-O bonds and reducing bond order, which lowers activation energy for decomposition. The practical consequences for CSP applications are logically sound. All statements are consistent with the original text and fundamental principles of ionic chemistry and thermodynamics.

issues: Overgeneralizes that all alkali cations (Na+, K+, Li+) have low charge density and thus better thermal stability; Li+ has a small ionic radius and relatively high charge density among alkalis, which is associated with lower thermal stability compared to Na+ and K+.

States that alkali cations collectively yield better thermal stability than Ca2+ without noting the important exception that Li+ can destabilize nitrates relative to Na+/K+, which follows from the charge-density argument in the cited text.
